questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurring episodes of headache for the past 5 months. During this period, she has had headaches for approximately 20 days per month. The episodes last for about 2 hours each. She describes the headaches as dull, pressing, and nonpulsating holocranial pain. The symptoms do not increase with exertion. She has no vomiting, nausea, phonophobia, or photophobia. She has been taking ibuprofen irregularly when the headaches are particularly severe. She has two children and has had a great deal of stress lately due to frequent fights with her husband. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amitriptyline is the prophylactic treatment of choice for chronic tension headache, which is defined as episodes occurring at least 15 days per month for more than 3 months. In addition to amitriptyline, lifestyle and behavioral modification (e.g., exercise, sleep, avoiding stress) are crucial for the treatment of tension headaches. The patient has had significant stress in her life, and avoidance of stressful situations would likely help to reduce her symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol and other beta-blockers are used for prophylaxis against migraines. Unlike this patient's symptoms, a migraine typically manifests with a unilateral, pulsating headache that is exacerbated by physical activity. It is accompanied by auras, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea/vomiting. Moreover, migraines last usually 4–24 hours.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin can be used to treat episodic tension headache, which is defined as 1–14 episodes of headache per month. However, this patient has chronic tension headache. Aspirin would be inappropriate, as it provides only temporary relief from headache. If aspirin is inappropriately used to treat chronic tension headaches, the patient may be at risk of GI bleeding and kidney disease. Furthermore, prolonged use of NSAIDs for chronic tension headache may cause medication overuse headache.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen can be used to treat episodic tension headache, which is defined as 1–14 episodes of headache per month. However, this patient has chronic tension headache and requests long-term management, for which acetaminophen would not be appropriate. Acetaminophen overuse puts the patient at risk of liver injury due to its toxic metabolites. The patient would benefit from a longer-acting medication instead.

E) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a first-line prophylactic agent for cluster headaches. However, cluster headaches typically manifest with agonizing, periorbital pain, associated with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms, such as conjunctival injections, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and/or partial Horner syndrome (i.e., ptosis, miosis, but no anhidrosis).

F) INCORRECT:

Valproate is sometimes used for prophylaxis against migraines. A migraine typically presents as a unilateral, pulsating headache that is exacerbated by physical activity. It is accompanied by auras, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea/vomiting. Migraines last usually 4–24 hours. However, this patient's headache is nonpulsating, is not affected by physical exertion, and only lasts 2 hours, making tension headache the more likely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's frequent holocranial headache episodes over the past 5 months, which are not associated with any further symptoms, make chronic tension headache the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-hour history of headache and neck stiffness. She describes the headache as a “constant band-like pressure around my head.” This sensation is accompanied by an increased sensitivity to loud noises. She did not have auras, nausea, or vomiting. She has experienced similar episodes intermittently over the past 12 months. The episodes began shortly after she started a new job, occur 1 day per month, and last for 4–8 hours. She has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Manual palpation of the pericranial muscles shows tenderness in the neck and shoulders. The remainder of the examination, including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the long-term treatment of trigeminal neuralgia, a condition characterized by very short attacks of severe shooting unilateral pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Attacks occur up to 100 times a day and can be triggered by stimuli like chewing. This patient presents with typical features of episodic TTH, for which carbamazepine is not indicated.
Image Description:

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

B) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is the prophylactic treatment of choice for chronic TTH, which is defined as headache episodes occurring at least 15 days per month for more than 3 months, and can be considered for episodic TTH if the patient has ≥ 10 episodes per month. This patient reports only one episode of TTH per month, so prophylactic pharmacological treatment is not warranted at this point. Moreover, amitriptyline is not indicated for the acute treatment of TTH.

C) INCORRECT:

Triptans, such as sumatriptan, are effective in the acute treatment of both migraine and cluster headache attacks. Migraine is characterized by recurrent episodes of intense unilateral, throbbing headache that may be preceded by an aura (e.g., visual disturbances) and is frequently accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and/or phonophobia. Cluster headache manifests with recurrent, 15-minute to 3-hour attacks of agonizing, strictly unilateral headaches in the periorbital and forehead region in combination with ipsilateral symptoms of increased cranial autonomic activity (e.g., lacrimation, conjunctival injection). This patient presents with typical features of episodic TTH, for which sumatriptan is generally not indicated.

D) CORRECT:

NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen, are the treatment of choice for acute episodes of TTH. However, frequent and excessive use of analgesic drugs (> 15 days per month) must be avoided as it can lead to medication overuse headache. While the exact pathophysiology of TTH remains unknown, triggering factors, such as lack of sleep, stress, anxiety, and depression, have been identified. Nonpharmacologic treatment strategies (e.g., lifestyle modification, cognitive-behavioral therapy, relaxation training) should therefore be considered in addition to medication. A headache diary can be helpful to establish the diagnosis and guide management.

E) INCORRECT:

High-flow oxygen therapy with 100% O2 is the treatment of choice for cluster headache attacks. Cluster headache manifests with recurrent, 15-minute to 3-hour attacks of agonizing, unilateral headaches in the periorbital and forehead region in combination with ipsilateral symptoms of increased cranial autonomic activity (e.g., lacrimation, conjunctival injection); up to 8 attacks per day are possible. This patient presents with typical features of episodic TTH, for which oxygen therapy is not indicated.
questions.hint: Once-monthly episodes of nonpulsating, pressing, band-like headache accompanied by a singular autonomic symptom (e.g., phonophobia) and pericranial muscle tenderness lasting 30 minutes to 7 days in conjunction with a normal neurologic examination are characteristic of episodic tension-type headaches (TTHs).

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports having recurrent daily headaches for the past 10 months. She describes the pain as a dull pressure-like ache in both temples, radiating to the sides of her head and down her neck, with a severity of 4 on a scale from 0 to 10. Each episode lasts for hours but less than a day.
The patient reports no aggravating or relieving factors with the headaches; in particular, she denies any positional quality to the headaches or association with her menstrual cycles. She denies nausea, rhinorrhea, or lacrimation with the headaches but notes that the pain is sometimes associated with light sensitivity. She has tried aspirin, acetaminophen, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs in the past, with minimal relief.
She does not take any prescription medications and has no family history of headache. She eats a regular diet and does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use recreational drugs.
On examination, her blood pressure is 123/70 mm Hg, her heart rate is 80 beats per minute, and her BMI is 25. Her neck is supple. Neurologic examination is normal except for slight tenderness to palpation over the frontalis, temporalis, masseter, pterygoid, sternocleidomastoid, splenius, and trapezius muscles on both sides.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for preventive management in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neither botulinum toxin injections nor citalopram appear beneficial in tension-type headache.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s history and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of tension-type headache. Tension-type headaches are very common, with a lifetime prevalence as high as 80% in the general population.

Classic tension-type headaches are bilateral and of mild to moderate intensity, with a pressing or tightening (nonpulsating) quality. They do not worsen with activity and are not associated with nausea or vomiting. They can be associated with photophobia or phonophobia but not both. The key physical finding is pericranial muscle tenderness, which can be assessed by palpating the pericranial muscles (frontalis, temporalis, masseter, pterygoid, sternocleidomastoid, splenius, and trapezius).

Treatment for acute tension-type headache includes aspirin or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs. Preventive treatment can be considered for patients who do not respond to acute treatment and for those with frequent headache (1 to 14 headache days per month) or chronic headache (≥15 headache days per month).

The medication with the strongest evidence of a prophylactic effect in tension-type headache is the tricyclic antidepressant amitriptyline. There is modest evidence to support use of the alpha2-adrenergic agonist tizanidine as adjunct therapy to amitriptyline.

In terms of nonpharmacologic treatments, biofeedback has been shown to provide benefit in preventing tension-type headaches, whereas acupuncture offers minimal and nonspecific benefit.

Key learning point: The most appropriate preventive medication for chronic tension-type headache is amitriptyline.

C) INCORRECT:

Sumatriptan is an effective abortive agent for migraine but is not used for prevention of any type of headache.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither botulinum toxin injections nor citalopram appear beneficial in tension-type headache.

E) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin may be effective in aborting a headache in the family of disorders loosely termed the trigeminal autonomic cephalgias, but it is not appropriate for use in preventing chronic tension-type headache.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl with no significant medical history reports having recurrent headaches for the past 10 months. She describes the pain as a dull pressure-like ache in both temples, radiating to the sides of her head and down her neck, with a severity of 4 on a scale from 0 to 10. Each episode lasts for hours but less than a day.
The patient reports no aggravating or relieving factors with the headaches; in particular, she denies any positional quality to the headaches or association with her menstrual cycles. She does note that the headaches are more frequent around times of extra stress (e.g., midterm exams). She denies nausea, rhinorrhea, or lacrimation with the headaches but notes that the pain is sometimes associated with light sensitivity. She has tried aspirin, acetaminophen, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs in the past, with minimal relief.

questions.solution:

C) INCORRECT:

Sumatriptan is an effective abortive agent for migraine but is not used for prevention of any type of headache.

D) CORRECT:

Classic tension-type headaches are bilateral and of mild to moderate intensity, with a pressing or tightening (nonpulsating) quality. Key learning point: The most appropriate preventive medication for chronic tension-type headache is amitriptyline.

E) INCORRECT:

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a three-month history of frequent headaches. The pain is usually bilateral, located in the frontal and occipital regions, and described as a constant pressure lasting for hours. She often notices it worsening during periods of high stress. She denies nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light or sound. Her medical history is noncontributory. Neurological examination is normal, but she notes mild neck muscle tightness during these episodes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tension-type headache manifests as bilateral, pressing, or tightening pain, often described as a constant pressure in the frontal and occipital regions. It is frequently associated with emotional stress and lacks nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia. Mild neck muscle tightness suggests pericranial muscle stress, a component of its pathophysiology. This headache type is the most common primary headache disorder and typically does not involve neurological deficits.

Key learning point: Tension headaches are characterized by a bilateral, pressing or tightening pain often described as a 'tight band' around the head and are commonly associated with stress.

B) INCORRECT:

Cluster headaches are characterized by severe, unilateral periorbital or temporal pain with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms like lacrimation and rhinorrhea. The bilateral, constant pressure-like headache described lacks these features and does not fit the episodic, excruciating nature of cluster headaches.

C) INCORRECT:

Sinus headaches typically involve nasal congestion, purulent discharge, and facial pain or pressure. The absence of these symptoms, along with the presence of occipital pain and stress-related exacerbation, suggests a different headache type. The normal neurological examination also argues against sinus involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Migraine headaches typically present with unilateral, pulsatile pain of moderate to severe intensity, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia. The described headache is bilateral, constant, and non-pulsatile, without these associated symptoms, making a migraine diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of recurring episodes of headache over the past 5 months. She reports having headaches on approximately 20 days per month, with each episode lasting about 2 hours. She describes the pain as dull, pressing, and nonpulsating, affecting her entire head. She does not experience vomiting, nausea, phonophobia, or photophobia. She takes ibuprofen irregularly when the headaches are particularly severe. She has two children and reports significant stress due to frequent conflicts with her husband. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propranolol and other beta-blockers are used for prophylaxis against migraines. Unlike this patient's symptoms, a migraine typically manifests with a unilateral, pulsating headache that is exacerbated by physical activity. It is accompanied by auras, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea/vomiting. Moreover, migraines last usually 4–24 hours.

B) CORRECT:

Amitriptyline is the prophylactic treatment of choice for chronic tension headache, which is defined as episodes occurring at least 15 days per month for more than 3 months. In addition to amitriptyline, lifestyle and behavioral modification (e.g., exercise, sleep, avoiding stress) are crucial for the treatment of tension headaches. The patient has had significant stress in her life, and avoidance of stressful situations would likely help to reduce her symptoms.

Key learning point: Amitriptyline is the first-line prophylactic medication for chronic tension-type headaches, defined as headaches occurring at least 15 days per month for more than 3 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a first-line prophylactic agent for cluster headaches. However, cluster headaches typically manifest with agonizing, periorbital pain, associated with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms, such as conjunctival injections, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and/or partial Horner syndrome (i.e., ptosis, miosis, but no anhidrosis).

D) INCORRECT:

Aspirin can be used to treat episodic tension headache, which is defined as 1–14 episodes of headache per month. However, this patient has chronic tension headache. Aspirin would be inappropriate, as it provides only temporary relief from headache. If aspirin is inappropriately used to treat chronic tension headaches, the patient may be at risk of GI bleeding and kidney disease. Furthermore, prolonged use of NSAIDs for chronic tension headache may cause medication overuse headache.

E) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen can be used to treat episodic tension headache, which is defined as 1–14 episodes of headache per month. However, this patient has chronic tension headache and requests long-term management, for which acetaminophen would not be appropriate. Acetaminophen overuse puts the patient at risk of liver injury due to its toxic metabolites. The patient would benefit from a longer-acting medication instead.
questions.hint: This patient's frequent holocranial headache episodes over the past 5 months, which are not associated with any further symptoms, make chronic tension headache the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-hour history of headache and neck stiffness. She describes the headache as a “constant band-like pressure around my head.” She has not experienced auras, nausea, or vomiting. These episodes began shortly after she started a new job last year and occur about once per month. On examination, manual palpation of the pericranial muscles reveals tenderness in the neck and shoulders. The remainder of the examination, including neurologic assessment, is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen, are the treatment of choice for acute episodes of TTH. However, frequent and excessive use of analgesic drugs (> 15 days per month) must be avoided as it can lead to medication overuse headache. While the exact pathophysiology of TTH remains unknown, triggering factors, such as lack of sleep, stress, anxiety, and depression, have been identified. Nonpharmacologic treatment strategies (e.g., lifestyle modification, cognitive-behavioral therapy, relaxation training) should therefore be considered in addition to medication. A headache diary can be helpful to establish the diagnosis and guide management.

Key learning point: NSAIDs such as ibuprofen are first-line therapy for acute episodic tension-type headaches, while prophylactic medications are reserved for frequent or chronic cases.

Amitriptyline is the prophylactic treatment of choice for chronic TTH, which is defined as headache episodes occurring at least 15 days per month for more than 3 months, and can be considered for episodic TTH if the patient has ≥ 10 episodes per month. Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the long-term treatment of trigeminal neuralgia, a condition characterized by very short attacks of severe shooting unilateral pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Attacks occur up to 100 times a day and can be triggered by stimuli like chewing. This patient presents with typical features of episodic TTH, for which carbamazepine is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Triptans, such as sumatriptan, are effective in the acute treatment of both migraine and cluster headache attacks. Migraine is characterized by recurrent episodes of intense unilateral, throbbing headache that may be preceded by an aura (e.g., visual disturbances) and is frequently accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and/or phonophobia. Cluster headache manifests with recurrent, 15-minute to 3-hour attacks of agonizing, strictly unilateral headaches in the periorbital and forehead region in combination with ipsilateral symptoms of increased cranial autonomic activity (e.g., lacrimation, conjunctival injection). This patient presents with typical features of episodic TTH, for which sumatriptan is generally not indicated.
questions.hint: Once-monthly episodes of nonpulsating, pressing, band-like headache and pericranial muscle tenderness lasting 30 minutes to 7 days in conjunction with a normal neurologic examination are characteristic of episodic tension-type headaches (TTHs).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of bilateral head pain described as a tight band around her forehead and occiput. The pain is constant, mild to moderate in intensity, and not worsened by physical activity. She denies nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or aura. Neurologic examination and vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies, including electrolytes and CBC, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This pattern of bilateral, pressure-like head pain that is mild to moderate in intensity and not worsened by physical activity is characteristic of tension-type headache. Tension-type headache is typically described as a tightening or band-like sensation and and does not cause migrainous or autonomic features.

B) INCORRECT:

Migraine can cause recurrent headaches. However, migraines often manifest with unilateral, throbbing pain of moderate to severe intensity, and are frequently accompanied by nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light and sound. The absence of these associated symptoms makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Cluster headache manifests with episodes of severe unilateral orbital or temporal pain lasting 15 minutes to 3 hours, occurring in cyclical patterns over weeks to months. Attacks are often associated with ipsilateral autonomic features such as tearing, nasal congestion, or eyelid edema. The lack of autonomic symptoms and the continuous, bilateral nature of this patient's pain make this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension can manifest with diffuse headaches. However, it typically causes visual symptoms (e.g., transient vision loss), pulsatile tinnitus, and signs of elevated intracranial pressure. The absence of visual complaints and normal neurological examination make this diagnosis less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis typically affects patients over age 50 and manifests with new-onset temporal headache, jaw claudication, constitutional symptoms, and temporal artery tenderness or thickening. Visual symptoms such as amaurosis fugax may occur. This patient's presentation suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old teacher presents to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of bilateral, pressing headache with moderate intensity. She reports similar episodes occurring 2–3 times per month for the past 6 months, each lasting 4–8 hours. She typically treats these with over-the-counter medication but ran out today. She denies nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia. Physical examination shows mild pericranial tenderness. Her last similar episode was 10 days ago. What is the most appropriate acute management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioids are not recommended for tension-type headaches and significantly increase the risk of developing medication overuse headache. Other medications are more appropriate and effective choices for acute treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiemetics are not indicated for tension-type headache treatment since nausea and vomiting are characteristically absent. This patient has no gastrointestinal symptoms that warrant antiemetic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Triptans are not indicated for isolated tension-type headache treatment. Triptans are specifically designed for migraine therapy and are not effective for the dull, pressing pain characteristic of tension-type headache.

D) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is used for prophylactic therapy in chronic tension-type headache and frequent episodic tension-type headache, not for acute treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- NSAIDs such as naproxen are first-line acute treatment for episodic tension-type headache.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with headaches that have occurred several times a week for the past month. She describes a bilateral, non-throbbing pressure sensation around her head, which is worse in the evenings after studying. She denies nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light. Her vital signs are normal, and the neurologic examination is unremarkable. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Bilateral optic disc swelling on fundoscopy
Tenderness on palpation of the scalp and neck muscles
Pain with chewing or combing hair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral optic disc swelling, or papilledema, is a sign of increased intracranial pressure. Headaches associated with this finding are often worse in the morning or with Valsalva maneuvers and may be accompanied by vision changes or other neurologic deficits. This patient's normal neurologic examination and evening headaches make this finding unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

A key physical examination finding of tension-type headaches is pericranial tenderness on manual palpation of the head and neck muscles, such as the frontalis, temporalis, masseter, pterygoid, sternocleidomastoid, splenius, and trapezius muscles. This finding supports the pathophysiologic theory involving myofascial pain referral. Tension-type headache is the most prevalent headache type, and management often includes simple analgesics, and lifestyle and behavioral modification.

C) INCORRECT:

A scintillating scotoma is a form of visual aura that is characteristic of migraine with aura. While migraine is a common cause of headache, this patient's clinical features, such as the bilateral, non-throbbing quality and absence of nausea or photophobia, make a diagnosis of migraine less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pain with chewing (jaw claudication) and scalp allodynia (pain from a nonpainful stimulus such as combing hair) are classic symptoms of giant cell arteritis. This condition is a form of vasculitis that typically affects individuals over the age of 50 and is inconsistent with this patient's age and clinical presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

These are cranial autonomic symptoms highly characteristic of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias, such as cluster headache. Cluster headaches are typically severe, strictly unilateral, and periorbital or temporal in location. This presentation is inconsistent with this patient's bilateral, pressure-like headache.
questions.hint: The bilateral, non-throbbing, 'band-like' quality of this headache, which is exacerbated by studying and lacks features like nausea or photophobia, suggests tension-type headache.
